intro: Lophopetalum toxicum, commonly known as the poisonwood plant, is a shrub native to parts of Asia and the Pacific Islands. It belongs to the family Theaceae and is characterized by its small, glossy leaves and showy yellow flowers. The plant contains toxic compounds, particularly in its roots and bark, which can be harmful if ingested. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, shaded environments. Due to its toxicity, it is generally avoided in traditional medicine and landscaping.
